magnetique 11/05/2020 10:54 PM
I'm very curious, what will prevent people to keep their hotspots physically still on the same very high dense hex, but just move them with app to neighbor hex with less density to avoid reward scaling? If there will be no mechanism to check, this will open new gaming possibilities through the assert location manipulation and will result to useless map of hotstpots, because it will not reflect the reality then...
para1 11/05/2020 10:58 PM
Yes if you are in a very dense hex and the neighboring hex is not very dense sure you can re-assert without actually moving your hotspot. It may be detectable with new anti-gaming methods especially if you are in the middle of a lot of hotspots but claim to be 700m away
22:59
also remember this is transmit reward scaling not all reward scaling so being in a very dense hex does not necessarily mean you will have low rewards if you can witness into lower dense areas (edited)
magnetique 11/05/2020 11:00 PM
ok so if I understand correctly, the signal check method (used today for witness validation) will be reworked to be more sensitive to detect this kind of manipulation, right? (edited)
para1 11/05/2020 11:00 PM
yes
23:01
even with current thresholds tho if you are surrounded by 5 other hotspots within a 400m radius and claim to be say 1km away that is likely detectable
23:05
and lets say that situation cant be detected, im not really that concerned about people lying +/- 500m. and because the HIP works at all resolutions from a target res up (say res 9 to res 0) each lower resolution covers a larger and larger area meaning you would have to lie about being further and further away in order to avoid that threshold
23:06
So sure you can move from a res8 hex with 6 hotspots to a neighboring hex with 1 other hotspot both there are still 8 hotspots under its parent hex which might be clipped.

para1 11/05/2020 11:10 PM
no and they are chain-vars so easy to changesif needed, although agree we should try to get them close from the start. Here is my suggestions that I played with: "res_vars": { "0": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 10000, "density_max": 10000}, "1": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 10000, "density_max": 10000}, "2": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 10000, "density_max": 10000}, "3": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 10000, "density_max": 10000}, "4": {"N": 1, "density_tgt": 250, "density_max": 800}, "5": {"N": 1, "density_tgt": 100, "density_max": 400}, "6": {"N": 1, "density_tgt": 25, "density_max": 100}, "7": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 5, "density_max": 20}, "8": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 1, "density_max": 4}, "9": {"N": 2, "density_tgt": 1, "density_max": 2}, } (edited)
23:12

para1 11/09/2020 11:04 PM
I would like to kindly ask for one thing that is still unclear for me. I'm trying to figure out, when a res 7 hex will turn from limit:5 to limit:10? Looking on the res8 map, I understand that in res 8, the hex neighboring with 1 occupied hex has limit:1, neighboring with 2 = limit:2, with 3 = limit:3, with 4 = limit:4. But on res7 map it seems to be a different key, which I don't understand yet. I see res7 hex neighboring with 5 another occupied hexes, and it has still the lowest limit:5
@magnetique a hex is only considered occupied if its density is >= density_tgt at its resolution so a res7 could be surrounded by other res7 with hoptsots in them, but if those surround hexsonly have 4 hotspots in them they dont count as occupied and the limits arent raised (edited)

12:08

para1 11/12/2020 12:56 PM
@gradoj the minimum witness distance is still required otherwise you could have two hoptsots in a closet witnessing eachother still getting rewarded (sure they would have a transmit rw scaling of 0.5 but they would earn). To provide "coverage" you need to be able to be witnessed a minimum distance away. This distance can be up for debate but it still needs to exist.
12:58
and as @jamiedubs mentioned, the HIP will evaluate all hex resolutions. Now realistically you could say we could ignore resolutions >say 12 as thats the position accuracy of hotpsot placements and there is little value in resolution 3, 2, 1, 0 as those are hundreds of miles apart but the implementation will definitely consider res 8 and *7 *and 6 and 5... (edited)

@JMF There is also a mod Helium Inc can do on the router ( I mentioned in #console channel) to get a list of all hotspots that received the data without having to pay for it. You'd only get signal metadata from 1 hotspot but you could get an idea on coverage redundancy. SOmething like:
Hotspot A received message {"data":"abc"," rssi":-110, "snr": 1.0} also received by hotspot B, C, D, E, F.
I agree with your interpretation of required coverage reliability. If there is no signal, it doesnt matter how smart or feature rich your product is, it turns into expensive garbage. So people developing or deploying products must have very high confidence in getting signal. (edited)

JMF 11/14/2020 1:34 PM
@para1 yea @Charles (nowisensors.com) can tell you coverage reliability testing has been a pain. They use some rules of thumb about what street level RSSI needs to be to have reliability at their nodes (-100 at street level).
13:35
-100 is a tough bar but people forget a lot of modes need to be inside a house or in a basement or something.
13:35
Hence the high density needed. Double redundancy with nodes within 0.3 miles is the rule they use.

@GP that is true but I dont think there is a good way to address that, coverage must be verifiable to be rewarded and if a covered hex is empty there is no way to verify coverage in that area. On timeline, we're looking at getting both of HIP 15 and 17 done together. As I mentioned in the other channel, I think it's important not to create too much rewards whiplash (by doing two distinct changes instead of just one) with the community. Seeing as the long weekend is upon us for the US, here's an update. We're targeting first week of December (week of 7th) for HIP 17 completion and subsequent activation. HIP 15 code has been deployed (silently) on the blockchain for the last few weeks but we need to keep iterating on performance improvements for HIP 17 since the hex based rewards scaling introduces a lot of new complexity to rewards calculations. Basic functionality is there but we need to continue internal testing. Progress can be seen in the branch: https://github.com/helium/blockchain-core/pull/677 We also need to generate some rewards distribution visualizations (which we'll drop in here for feedback from the community). Specifically we want to be able to quickly visualize the difference between existing vars, HIP 15 vars, HIP 15+17 vars. We're also waiting for more scaling results which should be available soon enough.

SralP 11/27/2020 12:39 PM
just gave it another thought. density_tgt shouldn´t be above 2.
Tushar 11/27/2020 1:33 PM
can you provide further explanation about why you think that?
para1 11/27/2020 2:09 PM
when thinking about density_tgt remember that in many "normal" topologies the density limit will be raised by meeting the occupied neighbor criteria. If you think density_tgt is too low that means you think there should be high reward for 2-3 hotspots in a hex without atleast 2 of the 6 neighboring res8 hexs having any hotspots in them. Because if 2 of the neighboring res8 hexs have atleast 1 hotspot in them then the limit gets raised to 2. If 3/6 neighboring res8 hexs are occupied then the limit is raised to 3. This is built into the HIP to account for these concerns. What density_tgt of 1 means is "dont reward more hoptsots going into the same location until some neighboring areas have hotspots, require location diversity before density can increase"
14:09
It doesnt mean 2-3 hotspots in a res8 hex is bad, in fact my proposal says up to 4 hotspots in a res8 is totally desired if sufficient neighboring hexs have hotspots in them (edited)

GP 11/29/2020 5:28 PM
I still wonder if we may be tuning for the wrong metric. Rather than the number of hotspots physically located in any given cell, I think that we should look at the number of hotspots that can hear each cell. If there were 6 hotspots circling a hilltop within a cell, each with a 120° sector antenna, the center of which is 60° offset from its immediately adjacent cells, it could provide excellent coverage, with two "ears" aimed in every direction of the compass. However, as we are currently planning, it would appear that the center cell is overpopulated with 6 hotspots Mind you, as I don't have a counter algorithm to offer, this is more or less an academic point. Barring someone implementing something which counts ears-per-cell, I fully support @para1 's proposal. (edited)
para1 11/29/2020 6:24 PM
@GP thats why its only transmissions that have the reward scaling. Those 6 hotspots with sectors will still get very high rewards if they can witness lots of hexs that aren't over-populated. The purpose of scaling down rewards for transmissions from dense hexs is the information gained by witnessing very nearby hotspots is low. Assuming omni antennas the value gained by witnessing a 6th hotspot in a res8 hex when you've already witnessed say 3-4 of them is low.
18:26
Now sure there a lot of dependencies and this may not be 100% accurate for all setups, like you said collections of very directional antennas on a mountaintop may not be fully modeled by this algorithm but it attempts to broadly cover the most common applications. If you are setting up 6 hotspots with fancy sectors on a hilltop, you know what you are doing and will tune to specific applications (again maybe you can witness much better which is where the bulk of the rewards are)
18:29
Also your "the number of hotspots than can hear each cell" is somewhat covered by HIP15 where after a certain redundancy is reached further witnesses split the pool of rewards for a given beacon instead of earning more (thus accounting for oversaturation in witnessing a beacon). The combination of HIP15 + 17 should work together to (get close to) maximally rewarding efficient coverage with the understanding there will be some "advanced" or "rare" topologies or setups that may be overly penalized. (edited)
18:33
15 limits witnessing saturation, 17 limits transmitting saturation and, in theory, together they balance each other out to optimize efficient coverage.
GP 11/29/2020 6:53 PM

para1 11/29/2020 6:56 PM

Jonah P 12/01/2020 8:44 AM
Having had a chance to go through the HIP, I think a case can be made for density tgt =2 for res 8 (density max at 4 can stay the same). I feel like there may be a problem with incentivizing owners to put hotspots into entirely new hexes at target =1 because a hex is only considered occupied if it has an interactive hotspot in it, meaning that going into a previously unoccupied hex (assuming not enough occupied neighbors) means either placing the hotspot close enough to neighboring hexes to witness hotspots there, or placing 2 in the same hex knowing both will only receive 1/2 rewards until nearby ones become occupied. Without help from other owners, someone building out the network with <5 hotspots will have a tough time making hexes â€œoccupiedâ€ to raise density limits in neighboring ones.
08:49
And I think density target = 4 would still ensure owners are rewarded for providing additional breadth of coverage as infrastructure begins to be built out in their area
JMF 12/01/2020 10:25 AM
I think there could be an argument there.
jcb1987
i don't understand this enough to be smart about it. but it would seem that dense cities with large buildings everywhere need a much higher density than rural or suburban areas.
para1 12/01/2020 11:35 AM
thats taken into account with the difference between density target and density max, cities will likely have neighboring hexs occupied thus limits will be closer to max. rural areas will be less likely to have neighboring hexs occupied thus closer to density target. Think rural areas or limiting basements full of hotspots for for density_tgt and cities for density_max. I took this exact need into account when designing HIP17
Jonah P

Without help from other owners, someone building out the network with <5 hotspots will have a tough time making hexes â€œoccupiedâ€ to raise density limits in neighboring ones.

Right the goal is to encourage:
placing the hotspot close enough to neighboring hexes to witness hotspots there
while being far enough apart to provide breadth of coverage. res8 hexs are ~450m in radius about 50% more than the witness limit anyway. So if you put two hotspots in the same res8 they would have to be at opposite ends of the hex, seems just as easy to put one in one hex and another in a different res8 neighboring the first.

magnetique 12/02/2020 1:48 PM
OK, I have a question. Rewards for transmitting hotspots and witnesses to transmitting hotspots will be scaled. So what else is here to be rewarded in PoC, when you say that will not be scaled? What is it?
para1 12/02/2020 1:50 PM
its all scaled but its the transmitter scale that matters not the receiver scale, so if hotspots A has a tx reward scale of 0.1 but it witnesses hotspots B, C, D each with a tx reward scale of 1.0 A will get high rewards for witnessing (which is where majority of reward pool goes with beaconing) and only see a decrease in reward for its transmissions. So hotspot A may see like a 10% drop in potential rewards vs a 90% drop. That's the key, a hotspots reward scaling matters much more for its witnesses than itself (edited)
13:51
still better to have a high reward scale for that transmit pool of rewards but its a limited slice of the pie, much more important to witness as many hotspots with high reward scales than to worry too much about your own
magnetique 12/02/2020 1:51 PM
aaah like this, thank you
richhomiecon 12/02/2020 7:31 PM
I also advocate for density_tgt =2 miners per res 8 hex. In areas lacking occupied neighboring hexes (and therefore limiting each hex to one miner) and with suboptimal broadcasting conditions, miners at opposite ends of adjacent hexes (or maybe even closer) may not be able to witness each other. Also, a minimum of 2 miners per res 8 hex will ease the location requirements and spur network spread from new owners more quickly. A move to a minimum of 1 miner per hex could make sense in the future once the network is more established, but we need mass adoption and quicker network spread for the next year or two at least.
para1 12/02/2020 7:59 PM
i see that point but I think 1 still makes more sense, its not a hard cap, and 2 within a hex wouldn't necessarily earn 1/2 as much as one in a hex (it depends on where they can witness) So at worse they only get 50% of rewards than if target=2 assuming they can only witness each other. There is nothing inherently wrong about putting 3 or 4 hotspots in a res8 hex even with limit=1, it just means witnessing those hotspots will result in lower rewards per witness (but you can get more witnesses). In fact, with hip15 target redundancy (N) = 4, 4 hotspots in a res8 hex earn more than 2 hotspots in a res8 hex even with density_tgt = 1. Its really important to consider how the two hips interact.

para1 12/08/2020 11:54 AM
Nope, none of what you said is right :). Well regardless of where your hotspots are they are "ok" if they are placed where they are asserted (not lying about location). But to be in valid witness range you must be 8x res 11 hexs away. If you are closer than this is doesnt matter which res9, 8 or whatever resolution hex you belong to, you cannot earn for interactions with that hotspot. Separately from witnessing, HIP 17 say any more than 1 hotspot per res8 hex will have its transmits (and witnesses to its transmits) earn less. Only if you have sufficient neighboring res8 hexs with hotpsots in them will the res8 limit be raised up to 4. Same logic applies at res 7 starting at 5 hotspots and eligible to raise to 20, res 6 starts at 25 and can raise to 100, etc.
Chuy
Is there a fixed # of hotspots per hex before rewards scale down?

para1 12/08/2020 12:03 PM
A hotspot next door to you will also mean your transmit reward scale would be 0.5. This means you will earn 1/2 as much for beaconing and those witnessing you earn 1/2 as much for witnessing you. THe idea behind this is there is little additional information gained about coverage by witnessing you or the hotsopt in the house next door, so hotsopts should be able to witness both of you bringing the earnings back in line.
12:03
ie 2 witnesses at 1/2 credit each = 1 witness at full credit

para1
Nope, none of what you said is right :). Well regardless of where your hotspots are they are "ok" if they are placed where they are asserted (not lying about location). But to be in valid witness range you must be 8x res 11 hexs away. If you are closer than this is doesnt matter which res9, 8 or whatever resolution hex you belong to, you cannot earn for interactions with that hotspot. Separately from witnessing, HIP 17 say any more than 1 hotspot per res8 hex will have its transmits (and witnesses to its transmits) earn less. Only if you have sufficient neighboring res8 hexs with hotpsots in them will the res8 limit be raised up to 4. Same logic applies at res 7 starting at 5 hotspots and eligible to raise to 20, res 6 starts at 25 and can raise to 100, etc.

Radrob 12/10/2020 10:36 AM
the hex size for density will be res8 (I believe) with a target density of 1 and neighbor hex number of 2. This means you will need a single hotspot in 3 neighboring hexes in order to add another hotspot to any of those hexes (for full rewards). If you add a second hotspot to a res 8 hex without having two neighboring hexes occupied, rewards will still exists, it just won't be maximized. (edited)

magnetique 12/10/2020 11:41 AM
rewards will be divided, if you have 2 on limit 1, it's like 1/2 = 0.5 for each, BUT the scaling is related only to receivers/witnesses so reward for witnessing these 2 on same hex for other hotspots in neighbor hexes. On the other side those 2 hotspots with scaling down to 0.5 will still receive full reward for witnessing those from neighboring hexes if they are not scaled

para1 12/10/2020 12:50 PM
LIke id suggest just walking thorugh the hip top to bottom evaluating it for one of your hoptsots. like do it manually. first calculate the clipped and unclipped densities for all resolutions your hotspot is in (I'd ignore the big ones like 4, 3, 2, 1, 0 just assume you are below target density). Then calculate your reward scale based on those clipped / unclipped densities, then pretend you did a beacon and calculate the rewards based on hip15 alone, then scale those rewards by transmit reward scale. Its a long process but probably a good way to get an understanding of how it works

panagos-o-enas
Spots outside the hex with res 11 ring 8 will earn normal rewards right? If two or more are within one hex of that size they get 0.5 as i understand
para1 12/12/2020 3:55 PM
No, I think you are confusing minimum witness distance with hip17's density calculation. Minimum witness distance is unchanged from hip17 and is a distance of 8 res11 hexs (as you describe). Any witness within this distance of the transmitter will receive 0 rewards, being outside of this distance makes you eligible for rewards which vary based on the HIP17 transmit reward scaling of the transmitter. (edited)
15:58
Density calculation is independent of witness distance and is based on the density of all hex resolutions from 10 to 4 (See "HIP17: Proposed chain variables" from https://engineering.helium.com/2020/12/09/blockchain-release-hip-17.html) For density calculation it doesnt matter how close or far away a hotspot is, all that matters is whether its in the same hex or not. For example a hotspot can be 50 meters away but be in a different res 5 hex, or 3 miles away but in the same hex, all depending on where the boundary lies. So consider the two things independently. Witness distance of 8x res11 hexs is completely independent of anything to do with HIP17 density requirements (edited)
GP
I am pretty sure that you are correct that witnessing can not be within a single cell. (edited)
para1 12/12/2020 4:00 PM
Not really correct, remember HIP17 is evaluated at lots of hex resolutions not just one so its totally possible to be in the same res8, 7, 6, 5, etc hex as the transmitter and still receive witness rewards. As I mentioned above its also possible to be a in a different hex as the transmitter and not receive rewards because you are still within the min-witness distance but across a hex boundary. Again they are independent of eachother
para1

gristleking 12/12/2020 7:51 PM
The allowed/optimum density changes depending on what is in neighboring hexes. If you want to start calculating how the rewards are divvied up for your specific hotspots, well, at that point you're getting into the "ELI18 and familiar with math" area. Long story short: If you can fire a water balloon slingshot from your hotspot and hit another hotspot, you're probably too close and will be penalized by HIP 15 & 17.

21:39
and remember Transmit reward scaling does not directly relate to overall reward scaling. So having a very low scaling factor for a hotspot does not necessarily mean it will be heavily penalized. It means those witnessing you will get low rewards for witnessing your beacons (because the assumption is they should also be able to witness your close by neighbors). So when you eventually run the numbers or see an updated map and your scale is like 0.1 dont think that means you will only be earning 10% of what you earn today.

para1 12/13/2020 12:18 PM
No, I am not sure how they are using density_tgt_res I removed that chain variable from the HIP proposal as how I was using it is obsolete (since we use density_max, N, and density_tgt for each resolution. you need to evaluate the density (and the density of neighboring hexs) at all resolutions from 10->4. Then multiply the clipped / unclipped densities at each hex you belong to together to get your tranmsit_reward_scale. For example: analyzing scale for hex 08c2a1008d4a39ff (res: 12) res: 0 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:802bfffffffffff 2200/2200) res: 1 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:812a3ffffffffff 1020/1020) res: 2 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:822a17fffffffff 765/765) res: 3 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:832a10fffffffff 539/539) res: 4 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:842a101ffffffff 246/246) res: 5 scale 1.000->1.000 (hex:852a100bfffffff 70/70) res: 6 scale 1.000->0.758 (hex:862a1008fffffff 25/33) res: 7 scale 0.758->0.631 (hex:872a1008dffffff 5/6) res: 8 scale 0.631->0.316 (hex:882a1008d5fffff 1/2) res: 9 scale 0.316->0.316 (hex:892a1008d4bffff 1/1) res:10 scale 0.316->0.079 (hex:8a2a1008d4a7fff 1/4)

panagos-o-enas 12/13/2020 2:19 PM
Ok so In the first one are our rewards going to be limited since there is only one per hex ( where you see dots)? Then in second case do we have some advantage due to being alone covering an area ( given there are witnesses)?
para1 12/13/2020 2:23 PM
In Example 1 the 5 hotsots in that hex will have a transmit rewards scale of 0.2 (1/5). So they will earn at most 20% as much for transmitting (beaconing) as they would if they were spread out. But this TRANSMIT reward scale does not effect their rewards for witnessing. So if they witness hotspots out of frame with a transmit reward scale of 1.0 they will get full witness rewards.
14:23
Thats why I say dont assume that a low reward scale means low rewards, it means low rewards for transmitting and low rewards for those witnessing you
panagos-o-enas 12/13/2020 2:27 PM
Ok i get it now ! So ideally you would have all hotspots alone without neighbors and as many witnesses
14:28
@para1 but neighbouring spots will earn as well from the ones that are alone and connect with them
para1 12/13/2020 2:34 PM
neighbors are fine, they dont penalize you. the goal is to witness as many hotspots with high scaling factors as possible. Lets break down example 3. here I named hotspots in each hex and provided the scalign factors:
14:37
lets assume C beacons and is witnessed by B, D, E, K. C has a tx scale of 0.4. B, D, E, K will all earn 0.4 reward units (due to C's scaling factor). Note K has a scaling factor of 1.0 and B has a scaling factor of 0.4 yet they earn the same as a witness (since their own scaling factor doesnt matter when witnessing)
14:38
Now K beacons and is witnessed by B, C, D, E. B, C, D, and E will all earn 1.0 reward units because its K that is transmitting so that's the only scaling factor that matters.
14:41
Now at the end of this C has earned 1.0 for witnessing and K has earned 0.4 for witnessing. So C has actually earned more (from witnessing) than K even though it has a lower transmit reward scale (edited)

Miami Cholo 12/14/2020 8:57 AM
Unfortunately its not that simple. Talking about the reward strucutre that will change once HIP17 is implemented: (1) your reward scale will be affected by the number of hotspots in the same HEX as you on res10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4. Meaning, maybe you are the only hotspot on a res8 HEX but there are 200 on the res7 HEX... then your rewards will be impacted too. There is a base limit for each resolution (res10: 1, res9:1, res8:1, res7:2, res6:2, res5: 2, res4:2) (2) the base limit will be increased if at least 2 surrounding hexes have more hotspots than the base limit...
08:57
This is where HIP17 is described:
08:57
https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0017-hex-density-based-transmit-reward-scaling.md
helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
08:59
Keep in mind that these are only for PoC rewards which are about 20% of all the rewards distributed.
1

para1 12/14/2020 2:22 PM
Some discussion maybe in #hip-discussion I'm not really a fan of it tho. Coverage is coverage I dont see why someone who has been there a long time provides any better coverage than someone who recently moved into the area. Early adopters get their benefit by earning when the number of hotspots is lower (meaning more HNT per PoC activity) and getting in before the halvenings. I dont think we need any other motivation. Also some first movers may provide bad coverage. Someone with a stock hotspot + antenna behind their window screen shouldnt get priority over someone that installed their hotspot later but has rooftop omni's. The solution to lone-wolfs is just to buy and install multiple hotspots at teh same time. (sure some ppl cant do this but then they dont earn, lone wolfs are pretty useless, no way around it)

magnetique 12/15/2020 8:50 AM
@Rafikiwi @j0nta it's not so hard if you understand the basics like: no (N=0) neighboring hexes (min.N=2 for raising the limit not reached): res8 hex = max 1 hotspot res7 hex = max 5 hotspots one (N=1) neighboring hex (min.N=2 for raising the limit still not reached): res8 hex = max 1 hotspot res7 hex = max 5 hotspots two (N=2) neighboring hexes (min.N=2 for raising the limit reached): res8 hex = max 2 hotspots res7 hex = max 10 hotspots and now when N=2 is already reached so on: three (N=3) neighboring hexes: res8 hex = max 3 hotspots res7 hex = max 15 hotspots four (N=4) neighboring hexes: res8 hex = max 4 hotspots res7 hex = max 20 hotspots (this is max limit = denstity_max variable) etc. for all the resolutions follow the table: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/773371162230128640/776552080210001990 bear in mind, that a valid neighboring hex is only that one which is occupied at least with: res8 = 1 hotpost res7 = 5 hotposts (this is density_tgt variable) when you have more than a limit it is a simple math then: I have 2 hotspots on limit 1: 1/2 = 0.5 scaling I have 7 hotspots on limit 5: 5/7 = 0.71 scaling If you crosses the limit on 2 resolutions than the final scaling is multiples of both scaling, for example on res7 I have scaling 0.71 and on res8 scaling 0.5, the final scaling is 0.71*0.5=0.355 This scaling is NOT applied to all the rewards but only to rewards of your witnesses, so hotpost which see other one with scaling 0.5 will get only 50% of possible reward, but if your hotspot see other one with no scaling (1) will get 100% no matter on its own scaling, so basically your scaling is worst for the neighbors then for yourself PS: this is just from my own understanding, research and replies from someone more erudite then I am, so it would be nice to confirm that it's correct and if so, would be nice to pin it as it will answer most questions which will land here after HIP15/HIP17 activation (edited)
3
1

GP 12/15/2020 9:19 AM
Are you saying that placing a hotspot into an already overpopulated hex cell will not reduce earnings on your witnessing of others, only on others witnessing of you?
GP
Are you saying that placing a hotspot into an already overpopulated hex cell will not reduce earnings on your witnessing of others, only on others witnessing of you?
magnetique 12/15/2020 9:28 AM
it depends, because if those you will be witnessing will be all from the same overpopulated hex, then your earning will be reduced as scaling comes into place, but if you will witness some other from neighbor hex which is not scaled then your earning will not be reduced, but more overpopulated the hex is, there is less chance you will be on the list as witness of these not scaled from neighborhood, as 5 witnesses will be the max from the start with first come first serve method (edited)

yes first who reports the beacon back into network

para1 12/15/2020 11:34 AM
its not punishment, coverage is coverage. Why is your coverage better than the other persons coverage? as a sensor / device using Helium you dont care who came first you care who provides the best coverage for your device. If the best coverage is provided by a hotspot that was deployed yesterday, great! use that one (edited)
1
11:36
also you need to look at it more holistically, a new hotspot added to a hex may reduce the transmit reward scaling for that hex but is also another hotspot that others can witness. So the odds of witnessing something in that hex goes up. So maybe you break even, or maybe you do even better on rewards. Its not as simple as "tx reward scale went from 1.0 to 0.5 therefore I am angry / screwed over"
11:38
and repeat the name of the scaling factor like 10 times: transmit reward scaling. Its a scale on transmits, not all rewards. (edited)

gradoj 12/15/2020 1:45 PM
How Transmit Reward Scaling is Used Its very important to understand that this is not a reward scaling for ALL rewards a hotspot will receive, it is scaling for a specific transmission and it effects the witnesses and transmitter. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0017-hex-density-based-transmit-reward-scaling.md
I believe scale values in the map are transmit scale values. So if my scale value is 0.1 whoever is witnessing my packets only gets about 10% of what they would have been
helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.

para1 12/15/2020 1:55 PM
thats what hex is visualized, but the reason you could have different scaling within the same res8 hex is that the res9 and res10 limits are being applied.
13:57
if the res0 to res8 has a net scaling of 0.5 and there are 3 hotsopts in a res10 (with a max density of 1) then those will have 1/3 of 0.5 or ~0.1666 Scaling factor
13:57
a seperate hotspot still in the same res8 hex but in different res9 and res10 hexs wouldnt have any additional scaling so would have a tx scale of 0.5. Hence multiple hotspots in the same res8 with different scaling

para1 12/15/2020 9:16 PM
so I think in reality slight over-density wont be a problem and a truly "optimal" setup would require like 3-4 hotspots per res8 hex across roughly 20-30 hexs (saturating a few res7's and maybe spanning a border across res6's. That means something like 50-100 hotspots. If some random person comes in and adds like 3-5 hotspots in your area, you would see a few of your hotspots scales drop from 1.0 to like 0.7-0.9. Overall your earnings might go down 2-5%. not really a big deal (edited)
21:17
and also if you have that much control over hotspot location, simply remove a hotspot from the same hex where "Tyler" put theirs and move it to the perimeter of this optimal network you setup expanding its area slightly (edited)
21:19
also remember, say two hotspots in a res8 that each have a tx reward scale of 0.5. if you can witness both you get identical rewards (as a witness) as if there was only one hotspot in that hex with a tx reward scale of 1.0. So there is no penalty on the witness side (but importantly no increase in reward). You would only see a penalty on transmits which are a smaller slice of the reward pie anyway.
21:20
So in general HIP17 doesn't severely penalize over density it just doesnt over-reward over-density
1
21:21
Hopefully in the next week or so we get a lot of data to crunch and evaluate the HIPs effectiveness and problem areas and have some real world examples to look at

ðŸŽˆhnt.ChrisV.btcâš¡ 12/16/2020 7:34 AM
one thing to consider, perhaps, is stage in network growth is a moving target, so no reason that this way of doing things has to go on forever
07:35
at first, it made the most sense to pack all your devices into dense urban areas. but now all of the existing coverage is concentrated in the same population centers. so at this stage in network development, those areas need to be dissipated outwards. so if we need to err on the side of "punishing" (as some are calling it) those denser areas that already have a ton of coverage, in the interest of spreading out coverage into more suburban/rural areas, that probably makes more sense at this stage. I don't think anyone would suggest there are no downsides. give/take.
07:36
later on maybe that critique would be more pressing, but the incentives can again be reworked. seems like valid observations, though.

so the scaling only affects the transmit, and the transmit is the challengee/beacon hotspot?
para1 12/16/2020 3:49 PM
it effects transmitters and receivers but the scaling factor that matters is the transmitter's scaling factor. So if hotspot A has a scaling factor of 0.1 and B has a scaling factor of 1.0. When A beacons and B witnesses, B earns 0.1 (A's scaling factor). When B beacons and A witnesses, A gets 1.0 (B's scaling factor)

Carrier-grade NAT (CGN or CGNAT), also known as large-scale NAT (LSN), is an approach to IPv4 network design in which end sites, in particular residential networks, are configured with private network addresses that are translated to public IPv4 addresses by middlebox network address translator devices embedded in the network operator's network,...

magnetique
@Rafikiwi @j0nta it's not so hard if you understand the basics like: no (N=0) neighboring hexes (min.N=2 for raising the limit not reached): res8 hex = max 1 hotspot res7 hex = max 5 hotspots one (N=1) neighboring hex (min.N=2 for raising the limit still not reached): res8 hex = max 1 hotspot res7 hex = max 5 hotspots two (N=2) neighboring hexes (min.N=2 for raising the limit reached): res8 hex = max 2 hotspots res7 hex = max 10 hotspots and now when N=2 is already reached so on: three (N=3) neighboring hexes: res8 hex = max 3 hotspots res7 hex = max 15 hotspots four (N=4) neighboring hexes: res8 hex = max 4 hotspots res7 hex = max 20 hotspots (this is max limit = denstity_max variable) etc. for all the resolutions follow the table: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/773371162230128640/776552080210001990 bear in mind, that a valid neighboring hex is only that one which is occupied at least with: res8 = 1 hotpost res7 = 5 hotposts (this is density_tgt variable) when you have more than a limit it is a simple math then: I have 2 hotspots on limit 1: 1/2 = 0.5 scaling I have 7 hotspots on limit 5: 5/7 = 0.71 scaling If you crosses the limit on 2 resolutions than the final scaling is multiples of both scaling, for example on res7 I have scaling 0.71 and on res8 scaling 0.5, the final scaling is 0.71*0.5=0.355 This scaling is NOT applied to all the rewards but only to rewards of your witnesses, so hotpost which see other one with scaling 0.5 will get only 50% of possible reward, but if your hotspot see other one with no scaling (1) will get 100% no matter on its own scaling, so basically your scaling is worst for the neighbors then for yourself PS: this is just from my own understanding, research and replies from someone more erudite then I am, so it would be nice to confirm that it's correct and if so, would be nice to pin it as it will answer most questions which will land here after HIP15/HIP17 activation (edited)

para1 12/18/2020 5:48 PM
there are some confusing boundary conditions with h3 that part of the h3 spec and provided libraries. for example: lat, lng = h3.h3_to_geo('8c194ac0404b1ff') h3.geo_to_h3(lat, lng, 8) Out[16]: '88194ac043fffff' h3.h3_to_parent('8c194ac0404b1ff', 8) Out[17]: '88194ac041fffff' So If I convert your res12 location to lat,lng and then find the res8 that contains that lat,lng you get hex 88194ac043fffff If I ask for the res8 parent of your res12 you get 88194ac041fffff. Since locations are really stored as h3 res12 the scaling factor (and pretty much everything h3 hex wise on chain) would use the h3.h3_to_parent('8c194ac0404b1ff', 8) method to figure out which res8 you belong to. So yea you will notice some weird boundary conditions that are just part of how uber's h3 works
1

are you doing density of each res recursively? ie the unclipped density at res6 is the sum of the clipped densities of its child res7 hexs
capcom 12/19/2020 12:45 PM
You can double check against our code as well
Anthonyra 12/19/2020 12:47 PM
@para1 It might be in there...
12:47
my error that is
12:49
I was just finding the total number of hotspots in the res in question and setting that as the unclipped value... but instead I need to add up all the clipped values of it's children hexes?
para1 12/19/2020 12:51 PM
yep thats how its implemented and teh best way to do it so you dont get penalized multiple times
12:54
for example if there are 2 hotspots in a res 10 without any limit increases they would have a scale factor of 1/2 at res10, 1/2 at res9 and 1/2 at res8 so immediately the two hotspots will have a tx reward scale of 1/8th. Where if you account for clipped children it would have 1/2 at res10, 1 at res9 and 1 at res8 giving it a scale of 1/2.
Anthonyra 12/19/2020 12:57 PM
Yea, that's where the issue is I think.. now how will I implement that haha
para1 12/19/2020 12:57 PM
the other benefit is it doesnt effect neighbors that are more spread out. So lets say there are 10 hotspots in a res10. This exceeds all density_tgt for res10 through res7. If another single hotspot is in the same res7 as these 10 hotspots it will have a scale factor of 0.45 (5/11 for res7). Significantly reducing its tx scale even tho there may be nothing else around it for 1km+. By localizing the penalty to the res10 it doesnt effect the single hotspot. (that res10 still counts as having hotspots in it and being occupied but it doesnt slam everyone else around it). This was the logic behind doing it that way atleast. (edited)
Anthonyra 12/19/2020 12:59 PM
Yea, I'm seeing that in some areas so that's exactly where my error is just need to figure out how to count up all clipped values

para1 12/19/2020 2:56 PM
for those interested, I put together a quick example of HIP15/17 interaction showing how HIP15 "dominates" HIP17 when # witnesses is <= N (HIP 15's target redundancy). Basically, up to a certain point it can be advantageous to stuff a well placed hex beyond target density if that means desired redundancy for witnesses is met. Once desired redundancy is met then the effects of HIP15 are limited and being over-dense penalizes. Id say this is somewhat desired behavior (good redundant coverage is more important that spread out, weak coverage). But this type of interaction between the two HIPs should be evaluated when tuning chain vars.

gradoj 12/20/2020 7:38 AM
I assume it was implemented as the hip states but looks like lone wolves have a scaling factor of 1 so not sure if they excluded non interactive hotspots in density calculation?
Getting interactive and losing interactive status There are many conditions that can be placed on hotspots before they are classified as â€œinteractiveâ€. As a minimum they need to have an assert_location transaction and must be able to transmit with valid witnesses (300m+ distance, valid metadata, etc). A hotspot should lose the status of interactive if its transmissions no longer have valid witness(es). This can be a count of unwitnessed transmission or a period of blocks where the most recent witness must be within that range of blocks (something like 10 times the expected transmission period). When a hotspot is not â€œinteractiveâ€ it will still be targeted for transmitting but it will not contribute to hex densities and the reward scaling factor will be 0.0 meaning no reward is given for transmitting. Hotspots with reward scale of 0.0 will still be motivated to transmit when challenged in order to discover witnesses and gain â€œinteractiveâ€ status.

para1 01/07/2021 2:08 PM
Im not sure there is a problem 100 hotspots per 36 sq km seems plenty. And remember the limits arent necessarily the desired number of hotspots its more the maximum amount of reward units that will be given out in that area. RU's are capped at 5 * density / beacon period (so for res 6 without raising limit 5 * 25 = 125 reward units every 240 blocks). This doesnt decrease if there are more than desired density hotspots in the area in fact it stays the same
14:09
unscientifically, and just through biased observation it seems more complaints are that rural areas arent seeing as much of a benefit and many urban / suburban areas are still doing quite well so Im not sure tuning to further increase urban areas is needed unless we see a specific problem
14:11

capcom 01/08/2021 12:30 PM
@vihu could probably opine on this
vihu 01/08/2021 12:34 PM
We do not do "interactivity" as intended in the original HIP, instead we have delegated that decision to the last time a hotspot issued a poc challenge. We store that information in the ledger, here's an example: (miner@127.0.0.1)1> blockchain_ledger_gateway_v2:last_poc_challenge(element(2, blockchain_gateway_cache:get(libp2p_crypto:b58_to_bin("112KDTvQmnc9vpFJPoyovp4mtuvLpi2r5cuKNYUaYsLHKyYT6QyC"), blockchain:ledger()))). 88831 So this particular hotspot last challenged at block#88831 and is considered stale. The minimum number of blocks for a hotspot to be considered interactive is configured as a chain variable and currently set to 3600, so any hotspot which has issued a challenge in the past 3600 blocks is considered eligible and interactive. The chain variable is hip17_interactivity_blocks: 3600
12:35
I'm currently investigating some inconsistencies in the map we've shared which questionably shows "stale" hotspots having scale values. Current theory is that it's just a bug in the exporter we use to gather the data and not an actual issue on chain.
Chuy
https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/404106811252408322/797157918910578758
